citeinfo.title: Population and Housing Density: U.S. Geological Survey GAGES-II time series data update

descript.abstract: This dataset consists of information regarding population and housing unit density for the conterminous United States sites of the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Geospatial Attributes of Gages for Evaluating Streamflow II (GAGES-II) dataset. The data include population density for the periods 1990, 2000, and 2010, and housing unit density estimates for decadal periods from 1940 to 2010.
descript.purpose: These data are intended as support for research efforts using the USGS GAGES-II sites.
descript.supplinf: This dataset is in support of study sites in the GAGES-II dataset (Falcone, 2011) and based on the watershed boundaries published there. Two time series are given here, in a single table: one series for population density, in units of persons per square kilometer (sq km) and one for housing unit density, in units of housing units per sq km. It is believed the data are comparable over time. The 1990 and 2000 population data are from the SILVIS Lab, University of Wisconsin-Madison (http://silvis.forest.wisc.edu/maps/wui), downloaded in 2005 (original data no longer posted), but transformed into rasters and published by Falcone (2016). These were 2000 block-level population data, and 1990 block-level data transformed to correspond to 2000 block boundaries, so as to be directly comparable at the block scale. (Some Census block boundaries change from era to era). Census blocks are the most detailed geographic scale for Census data. The 2010 population data are taken directly from the U.S. Census Bureau (U.S. Census Bureau, 2012) and are based on 2010 block boundaries. However, it is believed that when aggregated over watershed areas, such as published here, the differences between 2000 and 2010 block boundaries are negligible. Users should be aware however, that small differences over time, particularly for the smallest watersheds, may be in part due to differences in the methods and data sources for the different periods. The housing data for 1950-2000 are also taken from SILVIS data (http://silvis.forest.wisc.edu/data/1940-2030-housing-density-pbg, Hammer and others, 2004), and are based on modeled data from information in the 2000 Census. They were derived at a consistent geographic scale, which Hammer and others (2004) created and refer to as the "partial block group" scale - not as detailed as blocks, but more detailed than block groups. The 2010 housing data, as the 2010 population data, are taken directly from the Census Bureau at the block scale. They are thus, as with the 2010 population data, the most up to date and accurate data available. Nevertheless, it is believed they are consistent over time with the 1950-2000 data for the scale of the watersheds here. It was felt that providing the 2010 data in its most accurate form outweighed any minor inconsistencies with the data from prior years. References: Falcone, J.A., 2011, GAGES-II: Geospatial Attributes of Gages for Evaluating Streamflow, U.S. Geological Survey digital spatial data set, http://water.usgs.gov/GIS/metadata/usgswrd/XML/gagesII_Sept2011.xml. Falcone, J.A., 2016, U.S. block-level population density rasters for 1990, 2000, and 2010: U.S. Geological Survey data release, http://dx.doi.org/10.5066/F74J0C6M. Hammer, R. B. S. I. Stewart, R. Winkler, V. C. Radeloff, and P. R. Voss. 2004, Characterizing spatial and temporal residential density patterns across the U.S. Midwest, 1940-1990. Landscape and Urban Planning 69: 183-199. U.S. Census Bureau, 2012, U.S. Census Bureau 2010 Block Population and Housing data. U.S. Census Bureau, accessed October 2012 at ftp://ftp2.census.gov/geo/tiger/TIGER2010BLKPOPHU.

citeinfo.title: GAGES-II: Geospatial Attributes of Gages for Evaluating Streamflow

citeinfo.title: U.S. block-level population density rasters for 1990, 2000, and 2010

srcinfo.srccontr: Source data from which 1990 and 2000 population density data were derived

citeinfo.title: U.S. block-level population density rasters for 1990, 2000, and 2010

srcinfo.srccontr: Source data from which 2010 population and housing data were derived.
Source data from which 1950-2000 housing unit density was derived.

procstep.procdesc: (1) Source data for the 1950-2000 housing unit density data was downloaded from SILVIS Lab at http://silvis.forest.wisc.edu/data/1940-2030-housing-density-pbg in polygon format. These were converted to 100-meter (m) integer national raster grids, one for each decade.

(2) 2010 population and housing counts were downloaded from: ftp://ftp2.census.gov/geo/tiger/TIGER2010BLKPOPHU. This ftp site contains shapefiles of census blocks by state with 2010 population and housing counts. An area field was added to each state shapefile and calculated as area in square kilometers. A population density field was added to each state shapefile and the census source fields POP10 and HU10 were divided by the area field to get population density in persons per square kilometer, and housing density in housing units per square kilometer, respectively. The shapefiles were then converted to 60-meter (m) rasters based on the population density and housing unit density fields. The rasters were merged to create a national raster.
(3) Source rasters for 1990 and 2000 population density were obtained from Falcone, 2016. These were already-prepared block-level 100-m resolution rasters of population density for those eras.

(4) Watershed averages from the above grids (1950-2010 housing density and 1990-2010 population density) are based on GAGES-II watershed boundaries published in Falcone, 2011, using the "run_zonal.aml" script developed by Curtis Price of the U.S. Geological Survey (Curtis Price, written comm., 2007). This tool calculated zonal statistics from raster datasets.

(5) Informal tests were run to determine if differences in source grids at 60-m as opposed to 100-m were noteworthy, and in these data the differences are not significant. That is, whether or not the original polygon data were gridded at 60-m vs. 100-m made little or no difference for watershed-scale calculations of the population and housing data here.
